data.title: Physicians, dentists and medical students at Majdanek (female infirmary) – Doctors in Prison Uniforms

Brudkowska Aglajda née Rzeszowska

After several days at the camp, (…) I was recruited by the camp hospital personnel to work in my profession, but in reality it had very little to do with actual medicine. The sanitary conditions were appalling, there were no medicines or dressings available, which really put our skills as doctors to a test when trying to provide the patients with relative peace, warmth or the ability to lie down rather than stand for hours on end during roll-calls or do backbreaking work. It meant a lot. Besides, we had a chance to help – at least for a while – the elderly, the less resilient, the young. We hired fifteen and sixteen-year-old girls as nurses and they performed their duties with commendable devotion and enthusiasm.

— Aglajda Brudkowska, MD

On the fourth day of the Jewish Uprising, April 22, 1943, I was sent to Lublin to the so-called Luftschutzplatz in a transport of maybe 2,000 people captured at the ghetto. From there, after 8 days of selection and distribution of the prisoners to the camps in Treblinka, Trawniki, Poniatowa and at Majdanek, I was sent to Majdanek where I stayed until September 22, 1943. At the time, I ran the malarial disease block – for Greek women, and I was also the chief gynecology surgeon for the entire Majdanek infirmary.

— Alina Brewda, MD

Ludwik Benden

Born in 1900 in Düsseldorf, a turner and a waiter by trade. In 1932, he joined an anti-Fascist organization, for which he was arrested and interned at a camp. In 1937, he was briefly released, only to be arrested again in 1938, sent to KL Buchenwald, and later to Majdanek. His prisoner number was 1. Initially, he worked at the SS canteen as a waiter, later became the kapo of the infirmary. Polish prisoner-doctors remembered him particularly for performing surgeries despite his evident lack of qualifications. He euthanized patients by administering intracardiac injections of Evipan and participated in the selections to the gas chambers. On 22 July, 1944, he was placed on an evacuation transport to KL Auschwitz, from where he was relocated to KL Flossenbürg several weeks later. When he found out that his son had been killed on the eastern front, he decided to join the Dirlewanger Brigade tasked with the pacification of the population in the General Government and the USSR. After the war, he settled down in Düsseldorf where he worked in opera house administration until 1960.

Jan Říha

Czech national, born on April 29, 1894, in Protivina. In 1920, he graduated from the Faculty of Internal Medicine at Charles University in Prague. Before his arrest, he worked in Ostrava. He was actively involved in voluntary work for children and adolescents, wrote books, articles and health related self-help books. He was married and had one son. On October 5, 1938, he was arrested for aiding prisoners interned at the Ostrava prison. He was imprisoned at KL Sachsenhausen-Oranienburg and KL Dachau before his deportation to Majdanek on December 8, 1941. At Majdanek, he provided care to internal medicine patients. He died from exhaustion on June 7, 1943, after contracting typhus fever.

Owsiej (Awsiej, Andrzej) Bielenki (Bieleński)

Born on November 19, 1888, in Cherkassy to a poor Jewish family living in the east of Poland. He graduated from the Faculty of Natural Sciences in Petersburg and the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Warsaw. He gained considerable renown as an outstanding specialist during the Spanish flu epidemics of 1918. In 1926, he took over as the head of the internal medicine department at the Jewish Hospital in Czyste, Warsaw. Soon afterwards, he became one of the most sought-after physicians in Poland. He served as the chairman of the Medical Division at the Warsaw Charity Society. During the war, he continued to work at the hospital in Czyste where he cooperated with Ludwik Hirszfeld during the disinfection of the ghetto. After the relocation of the hospital staff to the ghetto, he took over as the head of the hospital department in Żelazna street. Following the defeat of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising, he was sent to the camp in Trawniki, where he worked as a physician until the fall of 1943. He was then transported by car to Majdanek and killed, most likely during the mass executions of Jews on November 3, 1943.

Włodzimierz Iljicz Diegtiariew

Born on July 13, 1915, to a peasant family in the village of Baraniki, Russia. After running away from home, he was placed in an orphanage. In 1938, he obtained his qualification in veterinary medicine from the Veterinary Institute in Novocherkassk. He continued to pursue his profession until November 14, 1940, when he was mobilized in Łomża to serve as a medical regiment surgeon. Taken prisoner in June 1941 near Żurawka, he was interned at the transitional camp in Zalew and later in Ostrowia Mazowiecka, where he served as chief surgeon in camp quarter D. He managed to escape in 1941, only to be recaptured in April 1943 in Dąbrówka. He was imprisoned in Łomża and later deported to Majdanek. At the camp, he worked as a physician at the tuberculosis barrack in field V. On April 17, 1944, he was deported to KL Auschwitz, later KL Flossenbürg and Regensburg. He managed to escape from an evacuation transport. In 1946, he returned to his homeland and resumed his veterinary practice. He died on November 20, 2001. His wartime vicissitudes were described by another former inmate at Majdanek, Igor Newerly, in the book “Chłopiec z Salskich Stepów” [The Boy from the Sal Steppe].

Stanisław Konopka

Born on May 24, 1896 in Pilzno near Tarnów in Subcarpathia. He graduated from the Faculty of Medicine at the Jagiellonian University in Kraków and obtained his doctorate from the Faculty of Medicine at Jan Kazimierz University in Lvov. In September 1939, as a career officer at the Center for Military Medical Education, he became the commandant of field hospitals for Polish prisoners of war. After the demobilization, he returned to Warsaw where he became active in the Union of Armed Struggle. Arrested by the Gestapo on January 8, 1943, he was imprisoned at Pawiak prison and later transferred to Majdanek. In the camp, he worked as a prisoner-physician at the field III dispensary, the surgery ward in field I, and from November 1943 at the infirmary in field V. In April 1944, he was deported to KL Gross-Rosen and subsequently to KL Leitmeritz (a branch of KL Flossenbürg), where he was liberated on May 8, 1945. After the war, he created the Main Medical Library in Warsaw, one of the 10 largest medical libraries in the world. He died in 1982.

Mieczysław Michałowicz

Born on September 10, 1876. He obtained his medical diploma in 1901. Since 1896, he was active in the fields of politics and community service, president and vice president of the University of Warsaw, founder of the Institute for Child Hygiene and chairman of the Polish Pediatric Association. In November 1942, he was arrested for involvement with the resistance movement and imprisoned at Pawiak prison, from which he was later transferred to Majdanek. He worked at the infirmary in the internal medicine ward. During his time at the camp, he contracted complicated typhus fever. Since June 1943, he conducted a series of lectures in various fields of medicine at the camp. From Majdanek, he was deported to KL Gross-Rosen and later to KL Leitmeritz. Upon returning to Poland in June 1945, he once again became involved in politics. He took the position of the President of the Alliance of Democrats Central Council and resumed his scientific and medical endeavors. He headed the Chair of Pediatrics at the Faculty of Medicine. He is now considered as one of the founding fathers of modern pediatrics in Poland. He died in Warsaw, on November 22, 1965.

Izrael (Jurek) Rotbalsam (Rom)

Born on July 22, 1909. He graduated from the M. Rej Secondary School for boys in Warsaw and subsequently from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Warsaw in 1932. He obtained his medical qualification in 1932 and proceeded to complete his internship at the Surgery Clinic of the University of Warsaw, gynecology department at the Jewish Hospital in Czyste, and internal medicine department at the Holy Spirit Hospital in Warsaw. In 1933, he completed active duty military training as lieutenant in the reserve. He was initially employed at the Pediatrics and Dermatology Clinic of the University of Warsaw, the Society of Aid for Poor and Sick Jews, and the communicable disease ward at the Bersohns and Baumans Pediatric Hospital. In 1939, he applied for an emigration visa to Palestine. On May 11, 1943, he was transported to the Treblinka extermination camp and from there, after selection, to KL Lublin. He was also deported to KL Buchenwald and later to KL Mauthausen where he survived until liberation in May 1945. After the war, he emigrated to Palestine, settled down in Tel Aviv and continued to work as a doctor.

Romuald Sztaba

Born on May 26, 1913 in Dąbrowia Górnicza. A graduate of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Warsaw and the Medical Reserve Officer Cadet School. He fought in the defensive war of September 1939 and was actively involved in the resistance movement. The latter lead to his arrest in Dąbrowa Górnicza in January 1941 and internment at the prison in Mysłowice. From there, he was transported to KL Auschwitz where he contracted typhus fever. In February 1942, he was deported to Majdanek. Initially employed as a warehouse keeper, in spring he took up the position of a physician at the surgical block 2 of field I infirmary. He also worked with typhus and scabies patients. He became involved with the camp resistance organization and cooperated with the Polish Red Cross. In April 1944, he was deported to KL Gross-Rosen and later to KL Leitmeritz. In 1955, he settled down in Gdańsk where he headed the Pediatric Surgery Clinic at the Medical Academy. In 1971, he was awarded the title of professor. He was a respected specialist in the fields of pediatric surgery and urology, and a lecturer at the Medical Academy in Gdańsk. He died on July 24, 2002.

Henryk Wieliczański (Izaak Halpern Wieliczański)

Born in 1903 in Łódź. In 1931, after obtaining his diploma in medicine at the Faculty of Medicine at Stefan Batory University in Vilnius, he moved to Łódź where he worked at the Jewish Hospital as an internist. He also authored numerous medical publications. During the occupation, he stayed in Warsaw, where he sheltered a Jewish woman, Sara Celnik, in his house. He headed the sanitation department of the Union of Polish Syndycalists, his code-name in the Home Army structures was “Zygmunt”. Arrested on January 8, 1943, he was imprisoned at Pawiak prison and later relocated to Majdanek, where he was employed as a physician at the infirmary. He organized the camp resistance structures and served the function of field V commandant of the Home Army resistance inside the camp. He maintained secret correspondence with Antonina Grygowa in which he informed her of the tragic situation of Jews and the mass murders taking place at the camp. On April 13, 1944, he was transported to KL Auschwitz. He was also a prisoner at KL Flossenbürg. In April 1945, he managed to escape from the transport taking him to KL Dachau. After returning to Poland he settled down in Łódź. He worked in his profession. He died on March 6, 1996 in Copenhagen.

Henryk Fenigstein

Born in 1913 r. In 1937, he began his studies at the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Warsaw and as a cadet at the Medical Officer Cadet School in Warsaw. Wounded in the defensive campaign of 1939, he was taken prisoner and interned at a POW camp until April 1940. After his release, he returned to Warsaw and worked as the assistant to doctor Józef Stein at the pathology department of the Jewish Hospital in Czyste, which was later relocated to the ghetto. Together, they performed nearly 3,000 autopsies, including 500 for a study on the hunger disease. He conducted clandestine lectures in anatomy and pathology. After the defeat of the Ghetto Uprising, he was transported to Majdanek and subsequently to the camps in: Bydzyń, Radom, Auschwitz, Durchgangslager-Krankenlager München-Allach (sub-camp of KL Dachau), Hessental, and Dachau, where he was eventually liberated on April 30, 1945. After the war, he worked in Munich, at the UNRRA hospital and the pediatrics ward of the University Hospital. In 1948, he emigrated to Canada and worked in Toronto as a psychiatrist. He died in 1993.

Stanisław Wrona-Merski

Born on February 2, 1883, in Żółkiewka. He studied medicine at the University of Warsaw. During WW1, he joined the Polish Legions and was active in the Polish Military Organization. A member of the 1st and 2nd term parliament for PSL “Wyzwolenie”. Arrested for his involvement in the resistance movement, he was imprisoned at the Lublin Castle prison until April 1941 and later relocated to KL Auschwitz. In February 1942, he was deported to Majdanek. He worked as a physician at block 2 (surgery) in field I and supervised wash-house hygiene. In April 1944, he was once again relocated to KL Auschwitz, where he worked as a physician. After the war, he returned to politics and re-associated himself with the People’s Party structures in Lublin. He died on March 5, 1963, in Warsaw.

Stefania Perzanowska

Born on August 26, 1896, in Warsaw. While working as an employee of the Health Department in Radom, she was also actively involved in the clandestine operations of a Home Army unit codenamed “Huragan”. Arrested by the Gestapo on the night of November 10 to 11, 1942, despite being subjected to fifteen brutal interrogations, she refused to name any of her fellow conspirators. In January 1943, she was transported with a group of other female prisoners to Majdanek, where she immediately became involved in the organization of camp life and care for the sick. Her dignified manner and exceptional knowledge of medicine allowed the establishment and expansion of the camp hospital for women. Doctor Perzanowska sheltered numerous prisoners at the hospital who were either at the point of extreme exhaustion or condemned to death by the Germans, she intermediated in the contacts with the Polish Red Cross and the Central Welfare Council. She would hire young, often underage girls as nurses to protect them from the cruelty of the female guards. After the war, she was employed at the Municipal Hospital in Radom. She chaired the Medical Committee of the Health Department and cooperated with the Society of Fighters for Freedom and Democracy (ZBoWiD). She died on August 16, 1974, in Warsaw.

Aglajda Brudkowska née Rzeszowska

Born in 1914, in Żytomierz. She graduated from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Warsaw. In 1941, she started work at the Polish Red Cross Hospital in Lublin. After its liquidation, she moved to Rzecznica Ziemiańska where she was arrested under the charge of involvement with the resistance. She was interrogated by the Lublin Gestapo in the building “Under the Clock” and later imprisoned at the Lublin Castle. In May 1943, she was evacuated to Majdanek. At the camp, she worked as a physician at the infirmary until April 1944, when she was placed on a female prisoner transport to KL Auschwitz. There, she was assigned the position of a physician at the Birkenau female camp hospital. She managed to escape during the so-called march of death. After the war, she worked at the Polish Red Cross in Lublin and as an assistant at the 2nd Clinic for Internal Diseases at the UMCS in Lublin. After 1953, she lived and worked in Puławy. She testified in the trials of Majdanek staff held in Düsseldorf. She died on November 14, 1983, in Puławy.

Hanna Narkiewicz-Jodko

Born on February 8, 1918, in Częstochowa. After graduating from secondary school, she began medical studies in Poznań. In 1939, she was a 5th year graduate at the faculty of medicine. In September 1939, she worked at the Maltese Hospital in Warsaw. She was arrested on November 11, 1942, and interned at KL Lublin. She worked at the infirmary as a physician and delivered children in the camp. Through the efforts of her family, she was released in May 1943. Despite her horrid experiences, she continued to participate in the resistance movement. She ran a healthcare centre for the freedom fighters in Sochaczew. After the war, she completed her medical studies and started work at the Józef Struś Hospital in Poznań, later at professor Adam Gruca’s Orthopedics Clinic in Warsaw as a pediatric rehabilitation specialist. She was actively involved in the Association of Former Prisoners of Pawiak, later also the Global Association of Home Army Soldiers in Warsaw, where she was responsible for maintaining the historical section. She testified in the Düsseldorf trial of Majdanek staff. She died on February 8, 2013, in Warsaw.

Wanda Ossowska

Born on April 28, 1912, in Kunice. She worked as a graduate nurse at the Polish Red Cross Sanatorium in Lvov. During the occupation, she served as a currier carrying messages between the Home Army Supreme Command and the Command of the Lvov District, she also supervised the liaisons of the Home Army Department of Offensive Intelligence “Stragan”. She was first arrested by the NKVD but betrayed no-one despite being tortured. She was later arrested again by the Gestapo in Warsaw in connection with the so-called Kalkstein case. She was tortured and held in isolation but refused to cooperate with her captors. In January 1943, she was transported to Majdanek where she worked with exceptional devotion at the camp hospital, tending to patients and training new nurses. During the evacuation in July 1944, she was relocated to KL Auschwitz, and later to KL Ravensbrück and KL Neustadt-Glewe. In 1945 she was arrested again and imprisoned by the NKVD for her involvement with WiN (Freedom and Independence, an anti-communist organization). After the war, she worked at the Orthopedics Clinic in Warsaw as a scrub nurse and assistant to professor Adam Gruca. She died on April 26, 2001, in Warsaw.

Danuta Brzosko-Mędryk

Born on August 4, 1921, in Pułtusk. She was arrested in Warsaw, for the first time on July 16 during her school-leaving examinations for the clandestine secondary-school. Together with the other students, she was released 3 weeks later. In August 1942, she was arrested again for her involvement with the Home Army’s Union of Armed Struggle and transported to Majdanek on January 18, 1943. Initially, she worked in the cleaning unit and was later selected for work at the infirmary as a trainee nurse. In April 1944, she was placed on an evacuation transport to KL Ravensbrück, and from there sent to work at the HASAG company in Leipzig (sub-camp of KL Buchenwald). After the war, she graduated from the Dentistry Department of the University of Łódź. She wrote several books about the camp and was one of the originators of the Society for the Protection of Majdanek. She testified in the trials of Majdanek staff members conducted in New York and Düsseldorf. She died on September 1, 2015, in Warsaw.

Barbara Todleben-Narbutowicz

Born in Lublin in 1917. Before the war, she studied biology in Warsaw. In January 1943 she was arrested by the Gestapo and placed in Pawiak prison. From there, she was taken to Majdanek. At the camp, she worked as a trainee nurse in the sanitation unit and participated in the registration of sick prisoners brought in to KL Lublin from other camps. In April 1944, she was placed on an evacuation transport to KL Ravensbrück, and from there sent to work at the HASAG factory in Leipzig (sub-camp of KL Buchenwald). After the war, she completed her studies and initially worked in Lublin, later at the Medical Postgraduate Training Centre in Warsaw. She died on October 19, 2002, in Warsaw.

Alina Brewda

Born on June 13, 1905, in Warsaw. She worked as a physician at Wola Hospital and at the Jewish Hospital as an assistant at the gynecology ward. She also ran her own medical practice. After the defeat of the Ghetto Uprising, she was placed on a transport to Majdanek. She worked at the infirmary for Jewish women and cooperated with doctor Stefania Perzanowska. In January 1943, she was relocated to KL Auschwitz where she served as the head doctor of block X. Apart from organizing medical care for women subjected to heinous medical experiments, she was also actively involved in the resistance movement. Sick and in the state of extreme exhaustion, she was eventually placed at the Birkenau camp hospital. In January 1945, she was evacuated together with other female prisoners to KL Ravensbrück and later to the camp in Neustadt-Glewe. With the care and great efforts of her fellow inmates she was able to survive until May 1945 when the camp was liberated. After the war, she emigrated to the United Kingdom. She worked as a gynecologist. She testified in post-war trials of Nazi war-criminals, including Rudolf Höss, in the trial of Majdanek staff members, in the so-called doctor’s trial and in the Dering vs Uris trial.

Helena Gall

Arrested in Warsaw and imprisoned at Pawiak prison in Warsaw on suspicion of Jewish descent. She was deported to Majdanek in early 1943. At the camp, she was registered as a Pole and worked at the camp infirmary office. On January 14, 1944, she was murdered after her true Jewish descent had been discovered. During the verification of documents held at the Poznań cathedral where, as she had testified, her wedding ceremony had taken place, her baptismal certificate was found which documented her conversion to Christianity.

Stefania Błońska-Balcerzak

Born on April 14, 1919, in Warsaw where she later studied at the Academy of Political Science. During the occupation, she was arrested together with her parents and interned at Pawiak prison in Warsaw. On January 17, 1943, she was transported to Majdanek. She worked at the sanitation unit and was also involved in cultural activities at the camp. From Majdanek, she was relocated to KL Ravensbrück. After the war, she worked as an actress in theatres in Olsztyn, Kielce, Radom, Zielona Góra, and Kalisz. Between 1961 and 1967, she worked as an instructor at the Regional Cultural Centre in Lublin. Between 1971 and 1988, she starred in a number of movies. She died on January 1, 2000, in Milanówek.

Tadeusz Stabholz

Born on October 16, 1916 in Warsaw to a family of doctors. When the war broke out, he was a student of medicine at the Warsaw University. In the ghetto, he worked as a physician at the Jewish Hospital in Czyste, where his father Henryk was the director and continued to secretly teach medicine. After the defeat of the Ghetto Uprising, he was sent to the Treblinka extermination camp, selected as fit for further work and transferred to Majdanek. Despite his medical education and experience, he was not able to secure a position at the infirmary. In the summer of 1943, he was deported to KL Auschwitz and was subsequently also imprisoned at Sachsenhausen, Dachau XI and Dachau IV (Kaufering). At the time of the Kauferning camp’s liberation, he weighed only 35 kg. He spent his first months of freedom in a hospital organized by the American Army. After the war, he married Ewa Weinzman and emigrated to the USA where he completed his medical studies in 1953, which allowed him to practice medicine in Ohio. He died on March 22, 2009.

Rev. Witold Kiedrowski (Witold Kołodko)

Born on April 16, 1912, in Buk Pomorski. He was ordained after graduating from the seminary in Pelpin. He served as a curate in Toruń and Wąbrzeźno. As a military chaplain in the Polish Army, he participated in the defensive war of September 1939. Under the assumed name of Kołodko, he worked at the Home Army’s Press Information Office attached to the Government Delegation for Poland. He was arrested in 1942 and placed at Pawiak prison. He chose not to disclose the fact that he was a clergyman and endured two months of interrogation and torture at the Gestapo headquarters in Szucha street. On 17 January, he was relocated to KL Lublin. He was registered at the camp under the name Kołodko and worked as an apothecary. Later he was also imprisoned at KL Auschwitz, Buchenwald and Ohrdruf. After escaping from a transport heading for KL Dachau, he made his way to the frontlines and passed over to the Americans. He served as a chaplain and liaison officer for the Third US Army. After the war, he studied in Paris where he obtained a bachelor’s degree in theology, canon law, and social sciences, as well as professorship in English. He headed the Minor Seminary in Paris. He received many decorations for his services to Poland and the Polish community in France. He died on January 20, 2012, in Paris.

Otto Hett

Born in 1913, in Augsburg. Before the war, he graduated from the faculty of medicine. He was arrested in December 1938 for political reasons and sentenced to 14 months in prison. Once his sentence was over, he was placed under “preventive custody” and interned at KL Dachau in April 1940. On December 8, 1940, he was transferred to Majdanek where he received prisoner number 15. Initially, he served the function of the infirmary kapo at the hospital barrack in field I, then he was reassigned as chief physician at the hospital for Soviet invalids in field II. Among the prisoners, he had a reputation of an honest man and a doctor trying to perform his duties to the best of his ability. He was murdered during the first evacuation transport heading from Majdanek to KL Auschwitz in July 1944.

Suren Konstantynowicz Barutczew

Born on March 11, 1896, in Susza. In 1922, he graduated from the faculty of medicine at the University of Don in Rostov. He was a gynecologist. Between 1922 and 1941, he worked as the head of the maternity ward at the hospital in Baku. In October 1941, he was conscribed to the 312th Division of the 50th Army as a surgeon. Taken prisoner by the Germans in the spring of 1943 in the region of Vitebsk and Orsha. He was deported to Majdanek in October 1943 together with a transport of Soviet war invalids. Interned in field II, he worked as a physician at the field hospital. He remained at the camp until its liquidation and then participated in the works of the Polish-Soviet Commission for the investigation of crimes against humanity committed at Majdanek. After the war, he resumed his professional career. He died on October 6, 1980.

Tadeusz Kosibowicz

Born on November 30, 1893 in Nowy Sącz. From 1921, he worked as the director of the County Hospital in Będzin. After September 1939, he sheltered wounded Jews in his hospital by providing them with false papers. He was arrested by the Gestapo on May 8, 1940, after being denounced by a German patient who discovered that he had been keeping a Jew at the hospital under an assumed name. Initially interned at the concentration camp in Sosnowiec, later at KL Dachau and KL Sachsenhausen. In October 1941, he was deported to Majdanek with a group of physicians. He worked at field I infirmary for some time before being transferred to field II infirmary. In April 1944, he was evacuated to KL Gross-Rosen, and 10 months later to KL Leitmeritz. After the liberation, he returned to Będzin and resumed his duties as hospital director. He died on July 6, 1971. In 2006 he was awarded the title of Righteous Among the Nations by the Yad Vashem Institute.
